oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beale Street Blues
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Beale Street; Handy Park; Handy, W. C.; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four pictures from the dedication of Handy Square. Possible cover for Beale Street Blues sheet music. Description from the cover: "Upper left-The crowd gathered in square; Upper right in car leading parade-W. C. Handy with Liet. G. W. Lee; Lower left-parade passing down Beale; Lower right-school children in floats passing reviewing stand. City, state and federal officials were among the long list of speakers who were heard over radio and caught by moving picture cameras."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Theaters on Beale
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Beale Street; Palace Theatres; One Minute Lunch Room; New Daisy Theatre;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A picture of the marquees of the Palace and New Daisy Theaters. Charles Starrett is starring in the "Hawk of Wild River" serial at the Palace. The prices on the window of the One Minute Lunch Room are: Jumbo Hamburgers - 20 cents, Ice Cold Beer - 50 cents a qt or 2 for 95 cents. Notes on the back read: Palace Theater, 324 Beale, 1953 C.D. and New Daisy, 330 Beale, 1964 MCD.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Historic P. Wee Saloon
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Beale Street; P. Wee Saloon; Crook, Leonard;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An artist's rendition of the P. Wee Saloon. Notes on the back read: "From an original water color by Leonard Crook"; "Birthplace of the Blues"; "It was in a back corner of Pee Wee's Place on a night in 1909 that W.C. Handy tuned up his band and wailed out the first 'Blues' ever to be written. He'd written it for a hot political campaign and named it the 'Mr. Crump' song. Mr. Crump won that election and Handy rode on his song from Beale to Broadway. Later changed to 'Memphis Blues,' a flood of rhythm went pulsating across the country to Paris to Singapore."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Crook, Leonard
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: #2034; Memphis - Streets - Beale Street - P. Wee's Saloon (Leonard Crook Watercolor)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2010, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lone Star Cafe
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Beale Street; Penczner, Paul; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An artist's rendition of Beale Street. Note on back reads: "'Beale Street' - Home of the blues, where W. C. Handy once blew his golden trumpet, this view is reminiscent of warm summer nights, laughter and the mingled odors of frying fish and barbecueing pork. Once an attempt was made to correct the street signs to 'Beale Avenue' but city officials soon bowed to public sentiment. Handy Park with its statue of the composer of Memphis Blues, St. Louis Blues and others, will soon be the center of a restoration project to preserve the flavor 'Beale Street' for future generations." 1966 Paul Penczner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Penczner, Paul
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: #2156; Memphis - Streets - Beale Street (Paul Penczner) - c.1966

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Red Sox Owners outside South Memphis Drug Company on Florida Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Florida Street; portraits; drugstores; baseball; Negro League baseball; South Memphis Drug Company; Memphis Red Sox;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The men standing in suits were the owners of the Memphis-based black baseball team, the Memphis Red Sox. Watermark in the bottom right corner of the image reads: Hook's Bros, Memphis Tenn. On back: "Red Sox Baseball Team. These distinguished gentlemen were the proud owners of a competitive black baseball team here in Memphis, the Memphis Red Sox. The Martin Brothers (Dr. J. B. [Martin] and others) were the principal owners. The team was originally owned by Robert Lewis, Sr."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Front Street in 1895
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Front Street; streets; buildings; churches; trains; railroad depots; horses; carriages; signs; J. H. Coffin Co.; George Arnold Company; 1890s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of Front Street taken from the Government building, looking northwards (c. 1895). Depicted are horse-drawn flatbed carriages transporting cargo. On the left is a train depot with train cars and smoke columns rising. Railways also line the westside of Front Street, with businesses on the adjacent side. Signage for J. H. Coffin & Co. (center) and George Arnold Company (right) are displayed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: black & white print from photograph or daguerreotype, 9 x 7 in.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Front Street in 1845
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Front Street; streets; buildings; pedestrians; businesses; horses; carriages; slavery; 1840s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An image of Memphis in 1845 sketched by an artist from Harper's Weekly. Caption reads: "LOOKING BACK ON MEMPHIS OF 91 YEARS AGO--James K. Polk was president of the United States, the Civil War was still a generation in the future, California and most of the west belonged to the Mexicans when a roving artist for Harper's Weekly sketched this picture of Memphis in 1845. In those days Memphis was a struggling river town of only a few thousand population and the city's first bank - The Farmers & Merchants - had only recently opened for business at Main and Exchange."
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: black & white newspaper sketch with caption, 8 x 3.75 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Confederate Veterans' Reunion on Front Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Front Street; streets; pedestrians; horses; carriages; railways; Customs House; Cossitt Library; 1900s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A newspaper photograph of Front Street taken in 1901. Pedestrians walk on Front Street outside the Federal Building. Newspaper caption reads: "Front Street nearly 40 years ago looked like this. The Federal Building as it was then, in its present location, is seen at the right and just beyond is the tower on Cossitt Library. The occasion was the Confederate Veterans' reunion in May, 1901. The picture is from the collection of photographs that Lem H. Johnson, 417 Edith, made as a young man, visiting Memphis from his native Holly Sprints [MS]."
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: black & white newspaper photograph, 5.75 x 4.75 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Front Street and Union Avenue
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Front Street; Union Avenue; automobiles; businesses; cotton trade; Cotton Exchange; F. M. Crump & Co.; J. G. Lonsdale & Co.; 1930s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The southeast corner of Front Street and Union Avenue, with a storefront sign for F. M. Crump & Co. This notice in the bottom right of the image reads as follows: "A CARD -- The undersigned having entirely withdrawn from any connection in business in New Orleans, respectfully informs his friends that he will open an office on the 1st of October, in the second store from the corner of Union and Shelby streets, adjoining J. G. Lonsdale & Co. He will be prepared with a large, convenient Cotton Warehouse immediately in the rear of his office, and will store, shiop or sell Cotton upon the most moderate terms, and with strict and unremitting attention to the interest of his patrons. Having now permamently located in Memphis, he earnestly request his old friends to call and patronize him again. -- Oct. 1 - N. Anderson." Penciled below: "American Eagle. Oct. 17-1845 -- x 1930 -- Cotton Exchange [indiscernible]" Duplicate image available at: "Memphis - Streets - Front Street - 1930 -- #6837C 4614"
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lauderdale Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lauderdale Street; Piomingo Avenue; streets; railroads; newspapers; businesses; Commercial Appeal; 1890s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sketch in a newspaper clipping from the Memphis Commercial Appeal: "This was a busy corner 35 years ago. The old Southern Railroad depot is across Lauderdale to the right. It was once the passenger station of the Memphis & Charleston. Lauderdale and Piomingo Avenue is at the transition point. Another old part of town will soon be swallowed by the new as a "for rent" sign hands [sic] on the Lehman store."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Madison Avenue
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Madison Avenue; Main Street; streets; newspapers;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping showing the intersection of Madison Avenue and Main Street. On the back of the clipping is the following caption, "Another view of Main and Madison, looking West toward the old Federal Building. The picture showing is now the Fisher Building which was remodeled to make its corner entrance level with the side walk. In this building was the Memphis City Ticket Offices of the Illinois Central Railroad. It was taken in Summer time, judging from the broad-brimmed straws worn by those dashing fellows making their way across Main Street. There were no traffic lights at that corner then and no one to prevent you from walking across at any time you wanted to try and beat a street car to the corner. At the alley west from Main, can be seen the Former First National Bank."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Madison Avenue
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Madison Avenue; Main Street; Front Street; streets; businesses; banks; newspapers; Commercial Appeal; 1890s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping from Commercial Appeal showing Madison Street looking toward Front Street. Caption on clipping reads,"Had you stood at Main and Madison 50 years ago and looked toward Front Street (dodging the passing mule cars as you did so) here is the scene that would have greeted your eyes, as sketched by an artist of that day. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; streets; Columbian Mutual Tower Building; postcards; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard comparing earlier view of Main Street to view in 1941. Written on the postcard is this paragraph, "Looking north on Main-Court Square's trees were then, as now, but the lofty Columbian Mutual tower has replaced the old Odd Fellows Building that stood at Main and North Court. Above, the scene then; below, the scene now."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street and Union Avenue
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; Union Avenue; streets; newspapers; businesses;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping showing the intersection of Main Street and Union Avenue. Caption on bottom of photo reads, "Main and Union - 1880. Wilkinson Drug Store, a cigar store and the Moss Rose Cafe stood on the corner where today rises the stately Farnsworth Building. Next to the Cafe was the Main Street entrance of the Gebring Hotel. Mule cart surreys, bicycles and buggies were teh traffic in those days. Between the car tracks were gas ... lights. This was the scene when J.N. Mulford open his jewelry store at 6 So. Main."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; Madison Avenue; streets; trolleys; businesses; newspapers; 1910s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping showing a view south down Main Street from Madison Avenue. Caption under photo reads, "And here is Main Street looking south from Madison in 1912. It's Summertime-and turning the corner off of Main into Madison is one of the famous Summer street cars with its long side steps high up from the ground and which caused many a young woman to blush when she was forced to display her legs to board it. The building showing to the left is a part of the old Moseley-Robinson Drug Store where you used to leave a note for your sweetheart to get later so she could keep her date with you. That was the 'Hub of Memphis' then."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Elliot, Casey
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Street Car Jam"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; Madison Avenue; streets; trolleys; businesses; newspapers; 1910s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping showing the intersection of Main Street and Madison Avenue with a line of trolleys and pedestrians. Caption under photo reads, "A Street Car Jam on Main Street twenty years ago. There seemed to be lots of jay-walkers in spite of the white-helmeted cop in the center of the Madison Avenue intersection, but automobiles were few and far between."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Architecture Was Ornate In 1888"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; Monroe Avenue; Union Avenue; streets; buildings; newspapers; Commercial Appeal; 1880s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping from the Memphis Commercial Appeal showing a view of Main Street in 1888. Headline for the clipping reads, "Architecture Was Ornate In 1888." Caption on the bottom of the clipping reads, "Main Street, with its ornate buildings, looked like this 50 years ago. This picture shows the east side of Main between Monroe and Union, the big building in the center being the Tennessee Block. Notice the mule-drawn street car rumbling down the thoroughfare."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "When Farnsworth Corner First Came Into Prominence As a Trade Center."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; Union Avenue; streets; newspapers; Commercial Appeal; 1900s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping from the Memphis Commercial Appeal showing the intersection of Main Street and Union Avenue. The headline for the clipping reads, "When Farnsworth Corner First Came Into Prominence As a Trade Center." Caption under the drawing reads, "One of the principal landmarks in the great business progress of Memphis has been the old northwest corner of Main Street and Union Avenue, which is to give place this year to the new Farnsworth Building. Depicted here is the old corner as it appeared 30 years ago. The old three-story building at 329 Main Street was occupied by D. Canale & Company, fruit and produce merchants, who boasted then of their fine wine cellar. The next store south, 331 Main Street then, as the street numbering started at the L & N. Railway Station up on North Main Street. There was 333, Moseley's Good and Bad Cigars. Gehrling's Moss Rose Cafe was at 333 1/2 Main Street. Besthoff's Pharmacy was at 3354, on the corner later the National Shirt Shop."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Main and Monroe"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street; Madison Avenue; streets; Commercial Appeal; newspapers; Peabody Hotel; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping with two views of the intersection of Main Street and Madison Avenue. Caption below photo reads, "Main and Monroe - The old Peabody Hotel stood where Lowenstein's store now stands, and the mule-drawn cotton wagons loaded with their bales rumbled past while men in derby hats and ladies in bustles promenaded the brick sidewalk. Compare this old scene (above) with today's modern scene at that corner (left) and note the changes in the architecture of Main Street's buildings."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved.
